respondent.name: BLUE HILLS BANK, FKA HYDE PARK SAVINGS BANK.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 14-116, Bullard v. Blue Hills Bank. Mr. Feldman.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How often, when you have a plan denied, is there typically -- okay, we'll try again, the judge says, I don't like this part of it, you address it and fix it.  In other words, you -- you try again, or maybe a third time, until you get it.  Okay, now it's perfect.  Let's go ahead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, very --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, if it occurs very frequently, why does it make sense to allow an appeal from the first denial?  Why not wait until -- why isn't it proceeding, the consideration of whether to confirm the plan, and you wait until it's all done, and the judge says, I'm not going to do this, I'm done, rather than -- if -- if you go through three versions of the plan, under your theory, you would have the right to appeal each one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The problem is that that may be because they never thought they had the right to appeal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- because it's very easy to get an interlocutory ruling if there's -- if the rejection of the plan is on a legal question.  I still don't understand why you didn't go that route.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yeah.  And the circuit said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- you already filed your appeal, so we don't have to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- is it only the -- the debtor who can appeal a rejection of a plan?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And what we say for 13 Alderson Reporting Company would apply to 11, as well, I assume?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, in 11, you -- you would have some well-heeled litigants who would -- would -- would appeal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- two or three times.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- what about the other side?  You say the other side could appeal. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So it's only in the important cases where this is a possibility?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, if it's an important case, then the avenues that are provided -- the -- the multiple avenues that are provided for an interlocutory appeal would seem to be satisfied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What would be the purpose of all those alternative interlocutory appeal if we accept your argument that in every contested matter a decision is final?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If we interpreted the -- Alderson Reporting Company the statute to say that there is jurisdiction here appeals from final judgments and final orders, do you -- is your case still just as strong?  Is this, in your view, a final order?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the first thing the judge said is that I want you to file an amended plan --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's what I don't understand.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- in a month.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So at least the judge didn't think it was done and over.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess it, again, maybe --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- the way you look at it is whether the proceeding is the confirmation or denial of this plan, or if the proceeding is whether to confirm or deny a plan.  Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If -- if the debtor had wanted to file a -- a new plan to try and satisfy the judge's concerns, would he have had to file a new action with a new number?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then why is it a final order?  That's what I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And are these all final orders?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?  Why -- why doesn't the debtor just say -- Judge says, debtor, I don't like your plan.  I'm not confirming it.  But if you amend it in this way, that way, or the other way, then I'll probably confirm it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay?  And then -- and then the debtor says, I don't want to amend it that way. Okay?  I'm not doing it.  No amendment filed.  Then what happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine, and then the debtor has an appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what's the problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, is that a good idea? What we do is we do there the same as any other case. We say I appreciate your staying this so I don't lose the advantage while I have an opportunity to appeal. And if the bankruptcy judge doesn't do it, you ask the appellate panel to do it.  That comes every day in the week, it comes up in criminal cases, civil cases all the time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does he have a good reason or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Then he'll get it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Courts make mistakes sometimes, by the way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it seems to me that to Alderson Reporting Company guard against a potential mistake, to potentially have appeals -- potentially anyway, none of us knows -- in dozens of cases, and then you say contested matters, there are all kinds of contested matters so we'll have to invent a new set of distinctions about which contested matters do count as final and which ones don't.  That seems to me to be throwing a very giant baby out with the bath water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And they're the only ones. And then -- then fee -- fee matters or not, though they're contested matters.  I have a list of about 47 contested matters here, that Collier has, and it seemed to me I couldn't figure out.  Maybe that's my failing, but I couldn't figure out what, under your rule, which contested matters were and which were not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's give --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's a given, isn't it, the -- the confirmation of a plan, the confirmation of a plan can be appealed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I thought your argument was that this is just the flip side.  You can confirm or you can deny.  Creditors can appeal if -- if it's confirmed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you're defining the contest as yes or no to this plan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I didn't see that.  Because I thought when a court confirms a plan then there is nothing left to do but execute the plan.  So obviously what you have to do is give an appeal, or the plan will be executed, the wages will be garnished, you'll be paying forever.  But when you deny the plan, nothing more will happen and, therefore, there is appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now that's what I thought the way it worked.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I didn't see why you give an additional set of appeals when only an amendment is at stake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Does that mean that they would have to say that there's a likelihood that their own ruling is wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Because if Justice Breyer were right, that that's a possibility, you would think that that would be a very good way to solve this problem. But you're just saying that they're -- the automatic stays are going to disappear on most of these debtors? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Am I -- am I correct in my recollection that your brief says that some jurisdictions have adopted the principle that you're urging and the sky has not fallen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What happened on the other side?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Did they all lose their houses or something in the interim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do we know that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, that's a pretty -- I mean, you know, I realize judges are difficult, but it seems to me if somebody was going to lose his house because you wouldn't grant a stay where he has some kind of an issue on appeal, that's a pretty appealing case for issuing that stay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or they're rather hard-hearted if they don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There is no lose-your-house exception to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I agree if there is some merit to your appeal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But are we then turning this on whether there's some -- you want to give a lot of appeals with no merit?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Reported cases, or any cases?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Reported cases, or any cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How much -- how much time, Mr. Feldman, would be involved?  So nothing is going to go on while this issue goes up on appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Something about your claim, yes, you can amend.  But as I understood, your claim is -- the answer you've been given is never.  You cannot have a hybrid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- to never amend -- to make a little change here or there.  It just can't happen at all. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You have --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: My problem still Alderson Reporting Company remains.  You have multiple ways of getting an interlocutory appeal.  You can go to the bankruptcy court.  You can go to the back court.  You can go to the district court.  And you can even ask the court of appeals to -- to grant one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you have four levels of protection in the event that a -- one court, like the one you applied to, says no to an interlocutory appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But if you have a novel issue of law like this one, you had all of those avenues.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's probably because there aren't that many denials that are based on novel issues of law. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Tripp, welcome.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that just begs the question.  Is -- if the discrete dispute is the confirmation of this particular plan, yes.  If the discrete dispute is consideration of the plan that is going to be part of the bankruptcy, then what you just said is wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But I think that the intuition --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If you're going to talk about the formality, the bankruptcy judge who doesn't want to be appealed, and I assume most of them don't, simply has to say, you know, I think I will probably deny this unless you come back with something and tell me that -- why this creditor shouldn't get, you know, 200 dollars as opposed to 10 dollars.  And then, although in substance, it's exactly the same as here, where he says this one's denied, but come back with another one --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And yet I assume you'd have to say there are different results in those Alderson Reporting Company two cases.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but creditors want to get on with it.  They want to get paid and out of it.  I mean, the problem here is that we're dealing with bankruptcy where speed is of the essence.  I mean, you've got dissipating assets and -- and all that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And yet, your creditors aren't terribly interested in delaying things. They want to move forward.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why isn't there, I mean, just the converse of what's been argued?  The debtor is -- there's an automatic stay.  He's living in his house every day.  He's submitting plans.  Let's say, the lawyer decides one every three days.  They're not dismissed, but they say, do it -- do it over again.  And I think this is great.  Now, I'll appeal each one.  And then I live in my house for ten years, because it takes a long time to resolve that.  I'm not saying that that's good or bad, but I just wonder why -- apparently, that hasn't happened in any of the these circuits, and you explain to me why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In other words, they would catch abuses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My example uses absurd plans to make a point, but the point is just as good where the plans are not absurd, but plausible, but there's this, that, and the other thing.  They're borderline cases.  They do and can take time.  You could and might proliferate appeals, so why hasn't that happened?  I'm -- that's the question.  Why hasn't that happened?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or -- or you ask for an interlocutory appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But do you think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- just -- just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- would the interlocutory appeal route work?  I mean, especially if this Court were to say in an opinion, you know, interlocutory appeals are really good for this exact purpose.  Is there anything in the structure of the system, is there anything in the incentives of judges that would prevent them from doing interlocutory appeals?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I didn't understand --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- the first part of your answer to -- to Justice Kagan.  You -- you said, well, there's some cases where the interlocutory appeals won't work because it's -- it's partly factual and so forth. But those are the very cases you say there's an automatic right.  Your position is there's a right to appeal.  You don't even need the interlocutory orders.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So it seems to me you're saying that now there are going to appeals in -- in -- under your view, that really shouldn't be taken at all. Alderson Reporting Company It seems to me that works against you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The -- the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The intuition that you're running up against here, Mr. Tripp --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- and the reason why people are searching to see if there are alternatives to your rule, is this idea that you're short-circuit -- Alderson Reporting Company short-circuiting what ought to be a kind of negotiated outcome.  And, you know, what I -- what I hear you saying is just, no, you're not, because nobody will ever want to short-circuit a negotiated outcome.  Is that -- is that your answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's a symmetrical argument, but we're asking a practical argument.  I'm Alderson Reporting Company not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- sure I accept the symmetrical argument, but I have to think about it. The practical argument is imagine you're a bankruptcy judge, and you get a plan, and it's not perfect, and you think, you know, they ought to change this, they ought to change that, they ought to change the other thing, it would be okay.  Now, if you say, go change it, go change it, I deny this one, but go change it, well, you'd have to take into account, gee, maybe I'll get an appeal.  God, this is going to slow everything down. It's just simpler to say, figure out some way around this.  I'm afraid, in other words, that the bankruptcy judges will -- would get confused on your approach.  Is there a concern there that the negotiation will be made more difficult? understand. final?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, forget it.  Forget it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Alderson Reporting Company Mr. Hallward-Driemeier.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The -- who -- who has the incentive to do that?  The incentive is someone like you, who has a pure legal question.  But they're saying there isn't an incentive to do that in a Chapter 13.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we have any --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we have any history, in the circuits that have the rule, that you can appeal of right from a denial of a plan proposal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- that's, you know, 10 years.  And these cases are coming up all of the time, and it seems as though you have a good natural experiment that goes on here.  And -- and it hasn't really led to the kinds of bad consequences that we're all --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- surmising about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When you argue as -- as you've just argued that this would give the debtors too much unfair leverage, how does that account for the fact Alderson Reporting Company that some of the very major creditors in the country on the Petitioner's side?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, they must not think there's too much leverage.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know why, in this case, the -- the bankruptcy -- whatever you call it -- the BAP, they would not certify an appeal?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, just to -- you were winding up to answer Justice Kennedy's question, and -- and you haven't -- you didn't throw the pitch.  So what is your answer to his question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: About -- about why the Bank of America and the United States are on the other side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it's already in their hands, isn't it, when -- when -- when it's a confirmation of a plan, right?  It's in the -- it's in their hands, in the parties' hands.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They -- they -- they want it to be in the debtor's hands? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So why do they want the debtor to have control of bringing an appeal? That's what I'm asking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You really don't know. It doesn't make any sense, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What -- what is the -- why is it that a debtor can't -- a creditor can't appeal? I mean, suppose you had a plan, the proposed plan said, I want to give $200 a month to Smith and a $100 to Jones, Alderson Reporting Company and the bankruptcy judge said, I'm sorry, I cannot approve that.  I want it the other way around.  Well, Smith is hurt by what he said, so why can't Smith appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But Mr. Hallward-Driemeier --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- I mean, you have to admit that it's very unpredictable.  Some judges will do it, some judges won't.  It won't be completely clear when they do it or why they do it, it will just be kind of luck of the draw.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, yes it is.  I mean, we're trying to figure out what's the best alternative of these systems in a world in which we're not particularly limited by text.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So it's quite important how the other alternatives work.  And if the interlocutory appeal alternative really isn't working because courts aren't using it for these kinds of purposes, then that's an important factor to know about, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are the other two? You started off saying there were three.  You got out the first. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I'm on -- on the edge of my seat, waiting to hear the other two. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Assume we don't think that's very effective.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that -- but you can see why that doesn't seem very good from anybody's point of view, including the system's point of view, right? You're going to file a plan that you don't like, that you don't want to live under, just in order to get an appeal right where you can come in and say, really what we want you to review is three-months ago when we had a Alderson Reporting Company different plan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, can we go back to the route that you just described?  Because it sounds strange to me. So the debtor's first plan is denied.        He comes up with a second plan.  Still in the second plan, the judge says, okay, he's in the position of being a winner.  I don't know of a situation where somebody who -- who asks for certain relief, got it, can then appeal that relief, because there is a relief that would be more favorable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I take it some courts will do it and some courts won't. But even, let's say you're right, that all courts will say, okay, now, that we're here, I'll go and I'll look back at the plan that you really wanted. I mean, you are -- you said, well, it wasn't his first choice plan, but he's accepted it. But maybe he's accepted it just to get the appeal on the other plan. If he's stuck with that latter plan, he's actually going to bag the whole thing and go into Chapter 7 or something.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And you're just making people run through hoops and -- and agree to plans that nobody is willing to live under.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now, I asked the other side this, I'd like to hear your answer, though it's more -- I -- this is a contested matter. Collier says there are endless contested matters. He Alderson Reporting Company lists about 47. All right. Now, when I asked, but does that mean in all those cases where there is an order in a contested matter, there will be an appeal? The answer was no. No. But this case is different because it has a beginning, middle, and an end, and it's a discrete proceeding. Now, is that, in your opinion, the correct test for sifting among contested matters? Are there other contested matters, where appeal, as if they were final orders, is allowed? What is the criterion? Will it, in fact, produce a nightmare? You're going to say, yes, but I mean, I'd like to know why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They don't either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, then I think they might now agree. So what is the standard?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So far, it sounds to me as if you may agree with them that the correct test is, is it a discrete proceeding within the larger case, and there's nothing that will help me get more specific than that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Am I right about -- on the standard of what counts as a final order for appeal?  I can't -- I don't want to put words in your mouth --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but that I can say there is basic agreement there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that is your -- it's still begging the question, because they're saying the -- the proceeding is the confirmation of a plan, and if the confirmation of the plan is a denial, that -- that ends that proceeding.  So you are begging the question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And they have resources to do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And Chapter 13 doesn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Hallward-Driemeier, I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- one of the things that confuses me about this case, quite honestly, is why you Alderson Reporting Company don't have more people on your side.  In other words, where are the creditors, and where are the amicus briefs from the creditors who think that your position is important in order to prevent all of these appeals that you say are going to ruin the system?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- you explained a reason why a particular company, creditor, is on the other side.  But, I mean, really, do you think everybody in the world is so intimidated by the Bank of America? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That no --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Maybe they thought you could handle it on your own. (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought that was the reason that -- that the -- the -- all are debating about what the incentives are.  Who's going to take more appeals and who isn't really has nothing to do with it. What they -- world they actually face is where nobody takes appeals, period, from denials anyway.  And -- and they say the bankruptcy judges are all over the lot on some of this, and they'd like to generate some appeals because they believe that then you would have a more Alderson Reporting Company uniform law.  It would be easier for the creditors as well as the debtors.  And I think that's their basic argument in their brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I don't know where to put that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So one -- one thing.  If you were -- maybe there's an argument against this -- but suppose for argument's sake I agreed with you on the basic point.  It would then seem important to put in the opinion there is a problem here about there being insufficient appeals to generate law, but there is a mechanism, namely, the interlocutory mechanism, which perhaps has been used too sparingly.  Now, what do you think of that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That was Justice Kagan's point initially.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You know, sometimes they even ignore our holdings.  Do you think they're not going to ignore this -- (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- this -- this piece of advice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And did they take our advice?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Feldman, two minutes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
